name: Tyler Washington
resonance_rationale: 'You're just getting started — new to the barbell or coming from another sport.' FINALLY. Someone sees me.

intent_rationale: Went from 'absolutely not' to 'I'd try it.' The beginner tier and built-in programs removed my biggest barriers.
conversion_rationale: Maybe. I'd need to see that the beginner programs are actually beginner-friendly — not just 'easier versions of advanced programs.'
price_rationale: Free. Good. I'm a broke freshman.
strongest_line: You're just getting started — new to the barbell or coming from another sport. Pick a built-in program, follow the plan, and let FreeWeight handle the math. Everyone starts somewhere.
strongest_line_why: Every single word of this is for me. I'm new. I don't know the math. 'Everyone starts somewhere' made me feel welcome.
weakest_line: Build training blocks, set percentages off real maxes
weakest_line_why: I still don't know my maxes. But at least V2 has a beginner path BEFORE I need to know them.
primary_objection: Do the built-in programs include exercise instructions or form guides? I don't know how to squat properly.
who_is_this_for: Broader audience now — from beginners to teams. I'm on the beginner edge.
what_would_you_tell_a_friend: Free lifting app that has beginner programs built in. You pick one and it tells you what to do. Way less scary than walking into the gym alone.
emotional_state_after: Cautiously welcome — I see an entry point
open_feedback: Massive improvement. V1 told me I didn't belong. V2 created a door for me. 'Everyone starts somewhere' is the single most important line on this page for beginners. My remaining concern is exercise guidance — I know WHAT to lift but not HOW to lift safely.
